message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of severe dandruff, nail pits, dactylitis, and periarticular new bone formation suggests psoriatic arthritis as the most likely diagnosis. Rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with erosions in the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint, while osteoarthritis typically affects weight-bearing joints. Reactive arthritis is usually associated with an infection or recent gastrointestinal or genitourinary illness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of severe dandruff, pitting of fingernails, and the presence of erosions in the DIP joint and periarticular new bone formation are all characteristic of psoriatic arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristic findings of dactylitis, synovitis, and nail pitting are most consistent with psoriatic arthritis. Plain x-rays showing erosions in the DIP joint and periarticular new bone formation are also more indicative of psoriatic arthritis rather than other options.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s severe dandruff and pitting of fingernails suggest psoriatic arthritis, which is known for causing dactylitis, synovitis, and erosions in the DIP joint. None of the other options are associated with psoriasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of severe dandruff, pitting of fingernails, and dactylitis with erosions in the distal interphalangeal joint and periarticular new bone formation suggests psoriatic arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis usually affects the proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints, while osteoarthritis doesn't typically present with dactylitis or periarticular new bone formation. Reactive arthritis usually follows gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings, including synovitis, dactylitis, and pitting of fingernails, are consistent with psoriatic arthritis. Erosions in the DIP joint and periarticular new bone formation also suggest this diagnosis. Rheumatoid arthritis usually affects the proximal joint before the DIP joint. Osteoarthritis does not present with synovitis or dactylitis. Reactive arthritis usually follows an infection and affects the lower extremities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of dactylitis, synovitis, severe dandruff, and pitting of fingernails suggest psoriatic arthritis, while the erosions in the DIP joint and periarticular new bone formation are typical findings in psoriatic arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest psoriatic arthritis, which often involves the fingers and toes and causes dactylitis. The presence of severe dandruff and pitting of fingernails also supports this diagnosis. Erosions in the DIP joint and periarticular new bone formation are characteristic radiographic findings in psoriatic arthritis. The other options are less likely based on the available information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of severe dandruff and pitting of fingernails suggests psoriatic arthritis, which often affects multiple joints and can lead to erosions in the DIP joint and periarticular new bone formation. Reactive arthritis usually presents after an infection, while rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with symmetric polyarthritis. Osteoarthritis usually affects weight-bearing joints and does not typically cause dactylitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of dandruff and pitting of nails suggest psoriatic arthritis. The erosions in the DIP joint and periarticular new bone formation are also characteristic of psoriatic arthritis, whereas osteoarthritis is more commonly associated with joint space narrowing and bone spurs. Rheumatoid arthritis can cause erosions but typically affects the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint rather than the DIP joint. Reactive arthritis is usually associated with infection and involves the larger joints such as the knee rather than the small joints of the finger.
